Like you our project has the need to compare files and large XML 
documents=
 and elements. The system is about 95% batch. Several other 
posts have sub=
mitted ideas on how you might do this. I wish I had 
realized that there we=
re tools out there to do this because I wrote it 
all myself. As you can se=
e there are options, so hopefully you will 
not need to do all the work tha=
t I did.

However, I did come up with a few techniques that you might find =

helpful. I keep all of the input files in a directory called TestData. 
Th=
e structure of this directory is identical to my source directory. 
Therefo=
re any test input files required by a.b.c.TestCase1 will be 
found in the T=
estData/a/b/c/TestCase1 directory.

I have a BaseTestCase that has a number=
 of methods that will return 
the handle to afile from the current TestCase=
 directory, in the form 
of a fileNameString, File, InputStream, etc. to th=
e satisfy the input 
requirements of the methods that I am testing. To acce=
ss the file, you 
call the appropriate method and give it the file name (wi=
thout the 
directory structure). The beauty of this approach is that you al=
ways 
know where you data is and if you refactor your class and move it to =

another package, you simply move you TestData directory to the 
directory =
that corresponds to your new package name.

For comparison purposes, I have=
 the identical structure in a directory 
called TestResults. Since typicall=
y only one file or XML would be 
compared per test method, I store the test=
 results in a file with the 
same name as the test method, followed by eith=
er .txt or .xml. I came 
up with the following little trick to get the test=
 method name:

    String testMethodName =3D new Exception().getStackTrace(=
)
[0].getMethodName();
    System.out.println(testMethodName);

The first t=
wo lines of all of our test methods are always these two 
lines. It is very=
 helpful to display the test method name in the 
system.out so you figure o=
ut which test method sys prints that must be 
added from time-to-time to a =
test method came from. We pass the 
testMethodName to the methods in our Ba=
seTestCase that do the file and 
XML compares. This class figures out the d=
irectory from the class name 
and we keep the root directory, which changes=
 dependent upon 
environment, in a properties file.

I also added an option=
 in the constructor of the BaseTestCase to 
indicate when the compare metho=
ds are executed whether they should do 
one of the following:
1. compare th=
e files and fail if the prior results not found
2. compare the files if the=
 prior results found, otherwise write the 
new results to the file
3. write=
 the new results to the file.

We almost always have option 2 turned on. Wh=
en the results change and 
we verify that the change is valid, we simply de=
lete the old file and 
run the test again. It is working very well for us.
=

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kavithask_98" <kavithask_98@...> wrote:
>
>=
 Hi,
> After running unit test, the output generates an xml file which has =

> say more than 300 lines.
> Now, I need to verify this with the expected =
xml file. Since, I have 
> lot of testcases like this it is not possible to=
 verify manually.
> Does Junit support this feature like comparing any two =
files 
checking 
> for the difference and then if something is not matching=
, showing me 
> the testcase and the lines due to which has failed.
> 
> If=
 yes, how to do the same.
> 
> Thanks in adavance,
> Kavitha
>
